text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name GEORGE HOBSON
Present Address 1411 GARNET ST. REGINA
Pioneer Address BORN. BRANDON, MAN.
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1893
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 12

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? different days

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? both ways

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? afternoon evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? if not was expected

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) at what time may they ask if you would stay I think the wife or women have set a table that she kept up

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? It was the afternoon the women of the house was sure to make up tea with something sweet

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? if so just describe how they did

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? oh yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Well my father mostly had them as I was young but remember ours was mostly church women to sew and buy one they had quilted him as he made felt quilted myself and drew a couple of different patterns for him and as a favor to a friend

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe

Reader! 21st best could other forget and in the winter there was the dances at different homes, so some played cards, some danced then was the old time square dance Waltz, minuet, or Shawtish other calls I don't know

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates

Well yes more or less they was in the different homes that is if the house was big enough for me some times would have from 25 to 40 just according to how many there was in a week. They was generally arranged by a group as we called them they held, they got the hypnotic play Wall the Square dance and get the girls or women to the cells. Really had some wonderful times there was no rough stuff then if you was sick out
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 3

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Different days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Both ways.

What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to make polite use of, or was there other expression on common?) 

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? 

Did the whole family go? Or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

5. Did you ever have "women" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Oh yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "meals were for," and how often they occurred. If not meals, what else was done?

Will you kindly supply any other facts? Any other things to add?

In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst here than more frequent in later years? Give dates if possible. What kind of parties were held, those presented by the family, those played country dance, etc., etc.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Did you ever have any "house party" over the weekend?

This was generally arranged by couples. My parents always had one for each child.

There were 25 or so guests at each dinner. Usually there were children, adults, and the hostess. Now, was the hostess always included?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

There was only about 2 or 3 dance at the school each winter as most of them wasn't homes. Of course all others dance this was some time out of the way and lunch, etc. We always had a Christmas tree & the prize judged for your school work. I think one of my brothers called Rob and his friends given me Nov 18-1897. My family was very kind & kept giving for good conduct. We also had picnics once a month at close of school at the haymow and back yard. How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

First but in the school district and that was at Brownhill School, about 4 miles south of Greenfield.

9. When was your first community hall built? Only had the school house.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Just the odd one do you just didn't bother them. Some way tried to live socially & friendly with everyone. Of course I know the odd one seen to get into some disagreement but we tried to be friendly to all.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for distant gatherings, and make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc., or were you close enough to come to the hall in town for other functions?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did they have family attendance? How many families and small children provided for? How many adults attended? How many horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? What card games were popular in the early days? What card games are popular today?

Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially—in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "newness," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated in parlor, etc.? 

This was the old law.

13. Was the obivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about obivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

This was mostly by the older men & girls only.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

This was mostly by the older men & girls only.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

There was the old lecture & debate arranged by the teachers or school board for education.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Soccer, football, fly kites, and we had a game show. The game was played with two pieces of wood similar to the stick, tied together with string, and you used sticks about 3 feet long. You tied the stick on the end of the string, and the girls used lacrosse sticks. What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

21A We played soccer, football, & lacrosse. I played soccer, haven't seen 100, but I've played full time on the team and I was still playing at age 16. I was considered very fast and I was always chosen to play. I played for a team that played in a league that was called the Eastern Mass. It's been around since 1975.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (and included the surrounding community). (There is space in the church hall for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lanterns and the slides?

CHILDCREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in games (marbles, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? How did they get along with others? Did they ever have a contest? How did they feel about it? What was the result?

What were the children's favorite games? How did they feel about them? What was the result?

22. What games did girls play in games (marbles, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? How did they get along with others? Did they ever have a contest? How did they feel about it? What was the result?

What were the children's favorite games? How did they feel about them? What was the result?

23. What games did boys play in games (marbles, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? How did they get along with others? Did they ever have a contest? How did they feel about it? What was the result?

What were the children's favorite games? How did they feel about them? What was the result?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Football field* (or football) and at our schoolhouse we had  
   *football field* (or football) played football, that was such a game of the kind.  
   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Yes most of them*

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *mostly the children*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *we always had some time to play games*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

**PICNICS AND SPORTS**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
   Give year and month if possible.  
   *around 1896*

26. Who organized it?  
   *a group from the school district*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *school district*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *no*  
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   *no*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *soccer, foot ball, races, jumps, races like long jump, ¼ mile, 220 yds, sack race, third legged, hurdles race, tug-of-war, log jump, pole vault, high jump, hop, step & jump, some races were played.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *general lunch, called generally a basket picnic*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *sandwiches, cake & cookies, apple pie, children drank milk, adults tea & cake on camp fire at the picnic grounds*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *started about 1 P.M., lasted to 6 or 7 P.M.*
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. That was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Just races as I took part in racing from the first picnic and I raced for many years and took part in running races up to 1949. That was the year I was selected in such competition.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Mostly soccer, football, men, mostly young people, some racers by teen age early twenties.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Soccer, Football.

What year was it started? How long did it continue?

1899.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

There was soccer teams at nearly all school district towns along C.P.R. main lines there was a good soccer league, made up of the following towns: Wapella, Morden, Head, Wolseley, Grenfell, Broadview, Lethbridge, Morden, Morden, Wapella. The best players from school ages to teenagers in the town then, from my school district only 5 to 7 played for Grenfell that often was as old as 12, but about 1907 to 1910 began to play in some local games.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
31. Describe any features or this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

32. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them and how they were played.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1894

How long did it continue? Until 1911

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1911, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

Then two teams came together and drew crowds everywhere.

a. First Team: Unknown

b. Second Team: Unknown

When was the first outdoor rink built in your community, and what was it used for?

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? 
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? 
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? 
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? 
   When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school textbooks as additional reading material?
7.

40. Was there an annual "sports day" become established in your community? If so, did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? If so, who was responsible for starting the first sports day? If not, what was the sports day usually held (that month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th)? May 24th

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   [Handwritten: Sun, Family Herald, Christian Heart.]

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   [Handwritten: From Sun, cancelled. Then this.]

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   No.
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   [Handwritten: I have the family Bible, my mother's letters, and some other things.]

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   - Yes
   - No

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   - [Handwritten text not legible]

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain ones.
   - [Handwritten text not legible]

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly lady Abertian packages of reading material?
   - Yes
   - No

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   - [Handwritten text not legible]

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   - [Handwritten text not legible]
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
Who started it? How long did it continue?
How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?
What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
9.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up part of your own songs or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke or something, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community?

Who started it?

How many were in it?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where,

If members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

JOBBES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or institutions of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, clubs of pioneer days; not already mentioned.

(Use back of pages, or extra sheets if necessary!)
